title: Dyfi Valley Way Walking Route

images.title: Mike White / Aberdyfi moorings
images.caption: Aberdyfi moorings near the start of the route. The river Dyfi runs swiftly close inshore at high tide, its course marked by a line of foam. See how the boats tug at their moorings. Beyond them the Dfyi estuary and mountains of Ceredigion.

images.title: Ian Medcalf / Pantperthog, Fforest Dyfi / Dyfi Forest, Pantperthog
images.caption: Pantperthog, Fforest Dyfi / Dyfi Forest, Pantperthog. Forest road with Tarren Gesail in the background.

images.title: Eirian Evans / Llanuwchllyn
images.caption: Llanuwchllyn. The village of Llanuwchlyn near the southern end of Bala Lake. This photo is taken from the B4403.

images.title: Trevor Rickard / Borth sea front
images.caption: Borth sea front. Borth is virtually a single road stretching some way down this four mile beach.

images.title: Ben Brooksbank / Eastward across Avon Dyfi valley at Cemmaes
images.caption: Eastward across Avon Dyfi valley at Cemmaes. Down in the bottom used to be the Mawddy branch of the Cambrian Railway (GWR) from Cemmaes Road to Dinas Mawddwy, which closed to passengers from 1/1/31 but was open for goods until 1/7/51. In the background are the Mynydd Cemmaes, rising to 1,296 ft.

images.title: Nigel Brown / View up the Dyfi valley
images.caption: View up the Dyfi valley near Dinas Mawddwy. Showing the mixed good and rough grazing, and commercial forestry, which is typical of the valley.

images.title: OLU, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Looking north towards Pen-y-bont at Machynlleth.

images.title: Nigel Brown / Phone box near Brynmelyn
images.caption: Phone box near Brynmelyn. The field beyond is part of the Dyfi Valley Caravan and Camping site and is used mainly for touring, with chalets and static caravans on the other side of the road.

description: A walk through the beautiful Dyfi Valley taking you from Aberdovey (Aberdyfi) on the coast to Llanuwchllyn before returning along the river to Borth. There is a long wooded section through Dyfi Forest and waterside sections along the river to enjoy. You'll also pass through the noteworthy town of Machynlleth as you skirt the edge of the Snowdonia National Park. Around here there's some nice riverside trails through the Lllyfnant Valley.
